newsitem.title: THAILAND: Thai baht strengthens, interbank rises.
newsitem.headline: Thai baht strengthens, interbank rises.

text.p: The Thai baht firmed against the dollar on Friday and demand for funds ahead of a bank holiday weekend pushed the interbank rate higher, dealers said.

The baht was quoted at 26.105-26.110 per dollar early on Friday against 26.110-26.115 late on Wednesday. The market was closed on Thursday. The Bank of Thaiand mid-rate was 26.09. The one-month baht/dollar swap premium rose to 6.25/7.25 satang per dollar against 5.00/6.00 satang on Wednesday.
Dealers said the spot market was quiet but forward swaps were active as reported problems with a proposed merger Finance One and Thai Danu Bank had spurred dollar buying forward.
"The spot is quiet but the forward swaps are quite exciting because of rumours about the Thai Danu and FinOne deal," said a local dealer.
"It seems like they may be rumours but if this deal doesn't go through there could be some problems in the financial system, so that is seeing people buying forward," he said.

Thai Danu Bank Plc earlier this year announced it was to merge with Finance One, the country's largest non-bank financial institution. Local newspapers reported on Thursday that the deal was in danger of collapse.
The baht/dollar swap was bolstered by the dollar's decline by 0.66 yen during morning trade in Tokyo.
The overnight interbank rate rose to 9.50-10.00 percent from 7.50-8.00 on Wednesday.
Banks, reopening after Thursday holiday, sought funds ahead of a three-day holiday weekend, dealers said. Fortnight bank reserve requirements are due next Wednesday.
Some traders said the central bank may have moved to tighten liquidity through open market operations late on Wednesday.
